Situation1: They coordinate closely with contractors to keep the construction schedule on track.
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story:
I glanced at my watch, heart pounding. The site meeting with the contractors was running late, and I could see the tension in their faces as we discussed the delays in the delivery of steel beams. As the architect, I was expected to keep everything on schedule, to be the calm center holding the project together. My phone buzzed—a reminder to vote today. I’d planned to slip out during lunch, but now, with the project teetering on the edge of another setback, I couldn’t just leave. 

Yet, as a voter, I knew I had a responsibility too. I’d set my ID aside this morning, but in my rush, I wasn’t sure if I’d packed the right one. If I didn’t have it, I could fetch another later, but that would mean leaving the site again, risking more time lost. The contractors looked to me for decisions, the city expected my vote, and I felt myself pulled in two directions, the weight of both roles pressing down, demanding I choose which expectation to meet first.
